nodes.text: Pro Forma Balance Sheet

Forecasting the balance sheet using the percent of sales method requires a few iterating steps. In any balance sheet analysis, we know that assets and liabilities/equity must be equal. The assets and liabilities/equity sides of the pro forma balance sheet will not balance, however, until we make assumptions about how our equity and debt will grow with sales. We see this point in
Table 18.3

, where we have taken a first stab at the pro forma balance sheet (we will explain the details of the calculation below). Our assets are projected to be $7501 more than our liabilities and equity. The imbalance indicates that we will need $7501 in
net new financing
to fund our growth.
The amount of additional external financing a firm needs to secure to pay for the planned increase in assets.
Net new financing
is the amount of additional external financing we will need to secure to pay for the planned increase in assets. It can be computed as:

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mrow><mtext>Net New Financing</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>Projected Assets</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Projected Liabilities and Equity</mtext></mrow></math>
data.alt: Net New Financing equals Projected Assets minus Projected Liabilities and Equity

config.activityTitle: First-Pass Pro Forma Balance Sheet for 2020

nodes.text: Let’s take a closer look at how we arrived at the $7501 figure. Because we are using the percent of sales method, we assume that assets increase in line with sales. Thus, total assets have increased by 18%, the same as sales. The liabilities side of the balance sheet is more complicated. The amount of dividends a company pays will affect the retained earnings it has to finance growth. Furthermore, any increases in debt or equity reflect capital structure decisions and require managers to actively raise capital, as discussed in
Chapters 14
and
. The bottom line is that we cannot simply assume debt and equity increase in line with sales.
In KMS’s case, it has a policy of paying out 30% of its net income as dividends. Thus, $2847 of its forecasted $9490 net income will be distributed to stockholders as dividends:

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left right" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mspace width="0.9em"/><mrow><mn>2020</mn><mtext> Net Income</mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mn>$</mn><mn>9,490</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace width="0.2em"/><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2020</mn><mtext> Dividends </mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>%</mo><mtext> of NI</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><munder accentunder="true"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>$</mn><mn>2,847</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="true">¯</mo></munder></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2020</mn><mtext> Retained Earnings</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>$</mn><mn>6,643</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>
data.alt: StartLayout 1st Row 1st Column 2020 Net Income colon 2nd Column Number dollar sign 9,490 2nd Row 1st Column negative 2020 Dividends left parenthesis 30 percent sign of NI right parenthesis 2nd Column ModifyingBelow minus Number dollar sign 2,847 With bar 3rd Row 1st Column equals 2020 Retained Earnings 2nd Column equals Number dollar sign 6,643 EndLayout

nodes.text: The $6643 in retained earnings (the remaining 70% of net income after dividends are paid) adds to stockholders’ equity on the balance sheet. As a result, stockholders’ equity is forecast to increase from $74,144 to $80,787 in
Table 18.3

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left right" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mspace width="0.9em"/><mrow><mn>2019</mn><mtext> Stockholders Equity</mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mn>$</mn><mn>74,144</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace width="0.2em"/><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2020</mn><mtext> Retained Earnings</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><munder accentunder="true"><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>$</mn><mn>6,643</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="true">¯</mo></munder></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2020</mn><mtext> Stockholders’ Equity</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>$</mn><mn>80,787</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>
data.alt: StartLayout 1st Row 1st Column 2019 Stockholders Equity colon 2nd Column Number dollar sign 74,144 2nd Row 1st Column plus 2020 Retained Earnings 2nd Column ModifyingBelow plus Number dollar sign 6,643 With bar 3rd Row 1st Column equals 2020 Stockholders right single quotation mark Equity 2nd Column equals Number dollar sign 80,787 EndLayout

nodes.text: We also assume that accounts payable will grow along with sales, remaining at 16% of sales as they were in 2019, so they are forecast to grow to $14,139. However, our initial assumption is that debt will remain the same, so our forecasted growth in liabilities and equity falls short of our forecasted growth in assets by $7501.
Common Mistake: Confusing Stockholders’ Equity with Retained Earnings

It is easy to confuse new retained earnings, total retained earnings, and stockholders’ equity. As in the example above, new retained earnings are the amount of net income left over after paying dividends. These new retained earnings are then added to the
total
accumulated retained earnings from the life of the firm. Total retained earnings makes up one part of stockholders’ equity, which also includes the par value of the stock and any paid-in capital.
